reference-wr.title: The Controller Configuration Script
reference-wr.shortdesc: The config_controller script presents a series of prompts for initial configuration of the Titanium Server system.

section.p: The script is used to configure the first controller in the Titanium Server cluster as controller-0. The prompts are grouped by configuration area. Details for each area are described in the following tables. Review them carefully before committing configuration changes to the controller. For configuration planning information, see the Titanium Server System Engineering Guidelines.

note.p: In many cases, you can accept the default values. Prompts requiring special attention are marked with an asterisk (*).

section.p: The configuration is applied only after all options have been specified. You can safely abort the configuration process at any time by pressing the Q key.

note.p: US62804 mention controller configuration input file:As an alternative to interacting with the script, you can prepare and use a controller configuration input file. For more information, see .

entry.p: Prompt
Comment
Is the current date and time correct? [y/n]:
Confirmation for the system date and time.

The controller periodically synchronizes the local system date and time with reference time servers configured later in the script. If the local time is not within about 15 minutes of the reference UTC time, the controller does not make the synchronization.
Enter new system date and time (UTC) in YYYY-MM-DDD HH:MM:SS format:
The date and time to apply locally, if the current system setting needs updating. incorrect.
Cinder storage backend [lvm]*:
The storage resource type for VMs and VM data.

note.p: The Cinder storage type cannot be changed after the system is installed.

li.p: For a system with storage nodes, type ceph.
For a system without storage nodes, type lvm. (This uses shares on the controller secondary disk).

dd.p: Provides a small-scale storage solution using LVM/iSCSI shares on the controller node. Note that this option does not use or support storage nodes in the Titanium Server cluster.
Provides a large-scale storage solution using a Ceph storage system. This option uses dedicated storage nodes in the Titanium Server cluster.

note.p: For Ceph storage, an infrastructure network is required.

entry.p: After the system is installed, you can selectively implement local compute node storage for VM data. For more information, see Titanium Server System Administration: .
Database storage in GiB [20]*:

p.ph: The storage allotment for the OpenStack database. As a reference point, a system with six hosts, 40 VMs and 120 tenant networks requires about 9 GiB.
For more details, see the Titanium Server System Engineering Guidelines.

entry.p: US68056 change to LVM onlyImage storage in GiB [19]*:

(For LVM storage only) The size of the partition to use for image storage. Consider the expected number of images and their storage requirements. A minimum of 10 GiB is recommended. The prompt shows the current available disk space.
US68056 addedImage conversion space in GiB [8]*:
The size of the partition to use for image caching and temporary image conversions.
Backup storage in GiB [20]*:

p.ph: The storage allotment for backup operations.
For details, see the Titanium Server System Engineering Guidelines.

entry.p: Volume storage location [0]:

p.ph: (For LVM storage only) The disk to use for a storage volume on controller-0.
A numbered list of available disks is displayed.
Type the number for the disk you want to assign.
Note that the primary disk is not included in this list.

note.p: US64033 note addedThe disk to use on controller-1 is assigned independently during controller-1 setup

entry.p: Volume storage in GiB [500]:
(For LVM storage only) The storage allotment for all volumes used by the guest instances. The prompt shows the current available disk space.

p.nameliteral: Configure LVM Provisioning type: thick or thin

entry.p: Cinder LVM Type [thin]:
The method for provisioning Cinder volumes.

pd.p: Use a dynamically sized volume. This offers support for secure deletion, but slower volume creation. You can improve volume creation times by using SSDs for the underlying physical disks.
Use a fixed-size volume. This offers faster volume creation than thin provisioning. Secure deletion is not supported.

note.p: This selection cannot be changed after installation.

entry.p: Enable SDN Network configuration [y/N]:

An option to use software defined networking as the Neutron network backend instead of locally managed traditional networking. For support details, see the Titanium Server Release Notes. For additional documentation, see Titanium Server Software Defined Networking.
If SDN is enabled, then an SDN controller connection must be defined before you can unlock compute nodes.

note.p: This selection cannot be changed after installation.

p.draft-comment: US62804 section added, although US62804 focuses on getting settings from a config file; the option to use a separate PXE boot network was added under US58516 Regions support, and US62804 incidentally makes this a choice in the config_controller script. US61937 / US65963 update for IPv6 on mgmt network

entry.p: Configure a separate PXEBoot network [y/N]:

p.ph: An option to configure a dedicated subnet for PXE booting over the internal management interface. This is for use where the internal network is VLAN-tagged. This is required when using IPv6 addressing on the management network.

entry.p: PXEBoot subnet [192.168.202.0/24]:
The subnet to use for the PXE boot network.
Management interface link aggregation [y/N]*:

p.ph: An option to use LAG for the internal management network.
If using LAG, you are asked for the name of the bonding interface, the bonding policy, and the name of an additional physical interface.

entry.p: If using LAG, you are asked for the name of the bonding interface to be created, the name of an additional physical interface to use for bonding, and the link aggregation mode to use. For more information, see .
Management Interface [enp0s8]:
The controller interface used for the internal management network.
The name of the physical interface to use to connect to the internal management network in non-LAG mode.
Management Interface MTU [1500]:
The maximum transmission unit for the internal management network. The default value is 1500.
US69810 newManagement Interface link capacity Mbps [1000]:

The bandwidth supported by the interface hardware. This is used to calculate the DRBD sync rate. The default is 10000 Mbps; adjust this setting if using hardware with a different link capacity.
If an infrastructure network is present, the DRBD sync rate is calculated based on the infrastructure interface link capacity, configured later in the script.
Management VLAN Identifier []:US62804 new
(For PXE boot network only) The VLAN ID for the internal management network. This is required if a PXE boot network has been configured.
US61937 / US65963 update for IPv6Management subnet [192.168.204.0/24]:

p.ph: The subnet to use for the internal management network.
The network does not need to be publicly routed, and therefore can be allocated from a private address range.

entry.p: Use entire management subnet [Y/n]:US62804 new
An option to reserve all or part of the management subnet for allocation by Titanium Server. By default, the entire subnet is available.
Management network start address [192.168.204.2]:US62804 new
(shown only if Use entire management subnet is set to n) The start of the internal management IP address range owned by Titanium Server.
Management network end address [192.168.204.254]:US62804 new
(shown only if Use entire management subnet is set to n) The end of the internal management IP address range owned by Titanium Server.
Dynamic IP address allocation [Y/n]:US62814 new

An option to use dynamic or static IP addressing on the management and infrastructure networks. By default, dynamic addressing is used. CGTS-3053 adds following sentence/updates noteIf static assignment is used, new hosts are not automatically added to the inventory when they are powered on. You must use the system host-add command to add them, and to assign IP addresses manually.

note.p: The infrastructure network is automatically assigned the same type of address assignment as the internal management network.

entry.p: Management Network Multicast subnet (239.1.1.0/28):CGTS-5681 new

The range of addresses that the system can use for multicast messaging on the management network. You can use this to prevent multicast leaks in multi-region environments. Addresses for the affected services are allocated automatically from the range.
This value is also used for the range of addresses the system can use on the infrastructure network.
Configure board management control network [y/N]:*
An option to use an internal baseboard management network for hosts equipped with iLO3, iLO4 or Quanta modules.
Select whether to configure an internal baseboard management network. This option is for use with hosts equipped with iLO (Integrated Lights-Out) modules.

note.p: To use an external baseboard management network (accessible from the OAM network), type N. For more information, see Titanium Server Planning:

entry.p: Board management control VLAN Identifier []:*
The VLAN ID designated for the board management control network.
The VLAN number designated for board management control traffic on the internal management network. For more information, see Titanium Server Planning: .
Board management control interface MTU [1496]:

p.ph: The maximum transmission unit for the board management control network. This must be at least 4 bytes less than the internal management network MTU.
If the internal management network MTU is greater than 1504, then the board management control MTU default value is 1500. Otherwise, the default value is 1496.

entry.p: Board management control subnet [192.168.203.0/24]:

p.ph: The subnet to use for the board management control network. You can safely accept the default value assigned to this internal network.
The suggested value belongs to the 16-bit block of private networks specified in RFC 1918. Use the suggested value, or any other 16-bit private address block.

entry.p: Configure an infrastructure interface [y/N]:*
An option to use an infrastructure network.
Select whether to configure an Ethernet interface for access to an infrastructure network.
For a system using Ceph storage, an infrastructure network is required.
Infrastructure interface link aggregation [y/N]:*

p.ph: An option to use LAG for the infrastructure network.
If using LAG, you are asked for the name of the bonding interface, the bonding policy, and the name of an additional physical interface..

entry.p: If using LAG, you are asked for the name of the bonding interface to be created, the name of an additional physical interface to use for bonding, and the link aggregation mode to use. For more information, see .
Infrastructure interface []:*

p.ph: The controller interface used for the infrastructure network.
You can optionally share the interface assigned for the management or OAM network.
The name of the physical interface to use to connect to the infrastructure network in non-LAG mode.
You can use a dedicated interface, or share the interface used for the management or OAM network. For a shared interface, a VLAN ID is required.

entry.p: Configure an infrastructure VLAN [y/N]:

An option to implement this network on the selected interface using VLAN tagging. If the same interface has already been selected for an untagged network, you must answer 'y' or abort the configuration.
Infrastructure VLAN identifier []:
The VLAN ID, if VLAN tagging is used.
Infrastructure interface MTU [1500]:
The maximum transmission unit for the infrastructure network. The default value is 1500.
Infrastructure interface link capacity Mbps [10000]:
The bandwidth supported by the interface hardware. This is used to calculate the DRBD sync rate. The default is 10000 Mbps; adjust this setting if using hardware with a different link capacity.

p.ph: The subnet to use for the infrastructure network.
The network does not need to be publicly routed, and therefore can be allocated from a private address range.

entry.p: Use entire infrastructure subnet [Y/n]:US62804 new
An option to reserve all or part of the infrastructure subnet for allocation by Titanium Server. By default, the entire subnet is available.
Infrastructure network start address [192.168.205.2]:US62804 new
The start of the infrastructure IP address range owned by Titanium Server.
Infrastructure network end address [192.168.205.254]:US62804 new
The end of the infrastructure IP address range owned by Titanium Server.
External OAM interface Link aggregation [y/N]:*

p.ph: An option to use LAG for the external OAM network.
If using LAG, you are asked for the name of the bonding interface, the names of two physical interfaces to use, and the bonding policy.

entry.p: If using LAG, you are asked for the name of the bonding interface to be created, the name of an additional physical interface to use for bonding, and the link aggregation mode to use. For more information, see .
External OAM interface [enp0s3]:*

p.ph: The controller interface used for the external OAM network.
You can optionally share the interface assigned for the management or infrastructure network.

entry.p: The name of the physical interface to use to connect to the OAM network in non-LAG mode. You can use a dedicated interface, or share the interface used for the management or infrastructure network. For a shared interface, a VLAN ID is required.
Configure an external OAM VLAN [y/N]:

An option to implement this network on the selected interface using VLAN tagging. If the same interface has already been selected for an untagged network, you must answer 'y' or abort the configuration.
External OAM VLAN identifier []:
The VLAN ID, if VLAN tagging is used.
External OAM interface MTU [1500]:
The maximum transmission unit for the OAM network. The default value is 1500.
External OAM subnet [10.10.10.0/24]:*

p.ph: The subnet to use for the OAM network.
You must provide a value for this external network, in accordance with your OAM network addressing plan.
Note that the default value provided by the script is probably not appropriate. Provide a valid subnet value as per your OAM Network's IP address plan.

entry.p: External OAM gateway address [10.10.10.1]:*
The IP address for the OAM subnet's default gateway. You must provide a value in accordance with your OAM network address plan.
External OAM floating address [10.10.10.2]*

The floating IP address for the OAM network. This is the address used to access the web administration interface or the controller console. You must provide a value in accordance with your OAM network address plan.
External OAM address for first controller node [10.10.10.3]:*
The IP address for the first controller on the OAM network. You must provide a value in accordance with your OAM network address plan.
The IP address to be assigned to the first controller on the OAM network. You must provide a value in accordance with your OAM network address plan.
External OAM address for second controller node [10.10.10.4]:*
The IP address for the second controller on the OAM network. You must provide a value in accordance with your OAM network address plan.
The IP address to be assigned to the second controller on the OAM network. You must provide a value in accordance with your OAM network address plan.
External OAM Network Multicast subnet (239.1.1.0/28):CGTS-5681 new
The range of addresses that the system can use for multicast messaging on the OAM network. You can use this to prevent multicast leaks in multi-region environments.
Nameserver 1 [8.8.8.8]:
Nameserver 2 [8.8.4.4]:
Nameserver 3 []:
The IP addresses of up to three DNS servers. The default values are addresses of public DNS servers available from Google. To continue without configuring DNS servers, press the C key.
NTP server 1 [0.pool.ntp.org]:
NTP server 2 [1.pool.ntp.org]:
NTP server 3 [2.pool.ntp.org]:

p.ph: The IP addresses of up to three NTP servers used to synchronize the Titanium Server cluster.
The default values are addresses of public NTP servers available from the NTP Pool Project.

entry.p:
The use of an NTP server is recommended. If no NTP server is available, the controller clock is used to synchronize the cluster. If necessary, you can continue without configuring NTP servers by pressing the C key.
CGTS-3867 note addedTo resynchronize individual hosts to an NTP server if necessary, see Titanium Server System Administration: .
License File [/home/wrsroot/license.lic]:
The path to a valid Titanium Server license file. The file name may differ from the default.
Enter wrsroot password age (in days) [45]:added while addressing CGTS-5681; part of US77644
The number of days before the wrsroot password expires.
Use secure (https) external connection [y/N]:
CGTS-4255An option to enable secure access for external REST APIs and the web server.
Install custom firewall rules [y/N]:US65292 added

An option to change the firewall rules for the OAM network. The default rules included with Titanium Server are recommended for most applications. If required, you can override or augment them. For more information, see the Titanium Server System Administration: .
Firewall rules file:US65292 added
The path to a file that defines custom firewall rules for the OAM network.
Use WRS provided self-signed certificate [y/N]:

CGTS-4255An option to use a self-signed certificate included with Titanium Server for secure REST API and web server access. This certificate is provided for evaluation purposes, and is not recommended for deployed systems.

note.p: For the current release, the certificate selected during controller configuration cannot be updated after installation.

entry.p: CA-Signed Certificate and Key file:

CGTS-4255The full path to a PEM file containing a certificate (signed by a Certificate Authority) and a Private Key (optionally password-protected) for secure REST API and web server access; for example, /home/wrsroot/pp-combo.pem.
Password for the CA-Signed certificate file [Enter <CR> for no password]:
The password for the CA-signed certificate, if a password-protected private key is used.
Create admin user password:
The password for the cloud admin user. This account is used to log into the web administration interface.
Repeat admin user password:
Password confirmation.
